author: absolutelylez
title: Get this figure
review: All elements of this figure are rare. The trousers, torso and face are customised to give a clown effect. The quality of the printing on the torso is excellent. The hair is very unusual but in a good way. The horn is unique but of low quality; there are odd lines and circles from the mold.

author: brixton
title: It
review:
Looking at the photos for the Lego mini-figure collection, the clown was the mini-figure that I wanted the most.  When I opened up the package and learned that I finally found the clown, I was a bit disappointed as it did not look as good as in the photo.  I still like the clown figure though as it does look great.

The clown is very colorful.  He has red and blue pants with red and blue patches on them,  He is wearing a green shirt with big red buttons and blue suspenders.  The red wig appears to be a new and unique piece, which I absolutely love.  The horn seems to be another new and unique piece for the set but it is the most disappointing piece in my opinion.  It appears to be too big and does not fit the scale of the mini-figure.

author: Jason_LEGO
title: Poor Quality
review: This is the first collectible minifig from this series I purchased. I wanted to buy one to see what they were like before I bought the whole collection. Thanks to Brickset I was able to choose the one I wanted with the bar-codes provided. Right after opening the package I realized the quality of these things was inferior to other minifigs and not up to par to the rendered pictures supplied from Lego. I am hesitant to purchase any more based on the quality of this one minifig. The colors are not as bright and saturated as the pictures, the plastic feels much cheaper and lighter and the printing on the fig is not very sharp or accurate. I would gladly pay double for a higher quality fig. Lego is one of the very few toys left that has a higher quality standard, however this seems to be changing. This one clearly is made 100% in China and it shows.

author: Orthobotrex
title: Hmmmm...
review:
This is one of my most anticipated minifig of the collectable series. The prints are not smudgy although they appear inferior to the other prints of LEGO minifigs, which look embedded into the plastic. But the headpiece is a plus, though I can see mold lines in them.
     What put me off was the horn. I have two of these, and one of them can't grip the horn as well as the other. On close inspection, it was wider at the section were it's supposed to be held. I was afraid to force it for I might break the hand. Also, the plastic appears somewhat pliable for both the horn and the minifg itself.
    It's pleasing to look at but do be careful with the print and the hand if the horn is too big for it.

author: RoboBrick
title: Average
review: When I first purchased this minifigure I was really excited. After building it I noticed that the horn didn't stay in the minifigures grip. The horn was of poor quality because I could see the molding lines. Also the horn felt like rubber overall I would give this set a 3 because of it's poor quality.

author: Kamex
title: Who's Laughing?
review:
A friend and I decided to  buy a collectible mini figure each to see what they were like. Hence, this was the first set out of the collectible mini figures that I bought. The figure was chosen at random.


 
Not a great deal to say about the figure really. At first I was excited, seeing as this is the only clown mini figure that I know of. The excitement soon wore off however. 

 
As soon as you hold the plastic you can feel the figure is not the same quality as the figures that are included in other Lego sets. The horn is particularly bad, with mold line everywhere which are very noticeable. The torso, face  and legs are nicely printed, and are unusual pieces, so theses will certainly appeal to some collectors. The hair is also a nice price, although it is so big, every time you try to rotate the figures head, the hair just rotates instead (although this may be because the head/neck was stiff on my figure).

 
Overall, purely a novelty item. Its perhaps one of the most interesting mini figures of the series, but certainly not worth £2.00, when you can buy say, the small city car for £3.50.

author: Carl
title: Circus Clown
review: The Circus Clown is a very cool minifig. He features a new horn piece and a red version of the afro/wig which appears only in this set and the Disco Dude, where it is black, from Series 2. His torso and legs are colourful and bright, and LEGO has captured the spirit of the clown perfectly in terms of the face. The playability and building experience drop of course simply because it is only a minifig, and I have only given it 5/5 for value for money because I got the entire series 1 and 2 for Christmas, thus getting the Clown for free. Overall this is a very cool minifig, and I would recommend him to most LEGO fans.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Collectable Minifigures (Series 1) - Circus Clown Review
review:
A few weeks ago I was very surprised that I found a new minifig of series 1 in a store. I got that bag and when I got home I opened it and I noticed that I got the Circus Clown. The figure looks very cool. I like the new hair piece and the new trumpet. The Circus Clown is a very colorful minifig and I'm glad to get a series 1 figure.

All in all it's a great set to get and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure.

author: Be_Burger
title: Here come the clowns!
review:
The Clown minifigure is an excellent minifigure from the original series. He is has some classic new pieces and helped start out our little circus troupe. Lets talk more about him.

Parts

  • The Clown has some nice new pieces. This is the first time the afro hair-piece was used, in the color red. He also has a great little trumpet, and a great clown suit. His clown face might be a little too realistic for some people... *shivers*

Playability

  • He is a very good figure. I think everyone likes clowns or are terribly afraid of them so I think you could have some fun with him (eg - making a circus show, giving him a knife, or hanging him upside down over a cliff)

Value

  • For TLG's $1.99 pricetag, I think this figure is definitely worth it! He has some great parts and is fun for everyone. He is a fantastic addition to any minifigure collection.

Overall

  • Overall, the Clown is a nice minifigure, but he probably will not make it to the top of your want list.

author: LEGOParadise
title: A little bit funny
review: The Clown minifigure is good and bad. Heres why: The printing on the clown is quite colourfull and detailed with patches, buttons and a bow tie. His hair and his horn are both new elements however the horn has some uneven colouring which is clearly visible. Also it would look much better if the Clown could hold the horn by the bulb as if he is hooting it. You can make a circus if you own the Clown, the Magician (Series 1) and the Ring Master (Series 2). Overall, I would not recommend this set unless you want to make a circus!

author: Berrus_Brickus
title: Just a step closer to my Ronald. . . .
review:
I won't be offended if you skip the intro, and get onto the reveiw.  If anything, I'll be relieved.

Well, there I was in Toys 'R' Us, I decided to purchase just one minifigure that day (as I had already speant enough at Target earlier that day), the one I wanted more than anything, The Clown. I had the end of his bar code memorized.  After tearing between one of two boxes, I found it (,or at least what I thought it was).  After opening it, I found a nurse.  Apparantly there are two barcodes on the bag. . . .

 

Anyway, though the nurse was a nice figure but not what I wanted.  You may or may not be able to imagine the disappointment, anyway I got over it.  But then, I recieved the little creep for Christmas, what a great gift.

Box/Instructions

So now onto somthing one may care about.  All of the Series 1 minifigures come in the same sealed, yellow polybag.  The instructions are just a little flyer showing how the put a figure together with a generic, yellow LEGO person.  On the reverse side there is a checklist showing all 16 of the Series 1 figures.

 

(Note: I only know what the Box/Instructions are like because of owning the nurse, you should understand upon reading The Build.

Parts

What is there here that is not to love?  We score an exclusive Red 'fro, a clown face, a lime green torso with white marks, a big red bowtie, and light blue suspenders.  The clown's legs are basic red hips, a red leg with a light blue patch, and a blue legs with a red patch.  The little creeper is accesorised with an exclusive gold horn (I would of prefered a knife, but oh well).  Also icluded is a black collctor's stand.

 

I only have two complaints,

  • 1. Chinese Plastic
  • 2. I would of prefered if the head was all white, but that's an opinion

Minifigure(s)

See Parts

The build

I actually didn't build this, he was assembled in the box.  But I can tell you from building the nurse, it is considerbly less enjoyable than standard LEGO figures, as chinese minis are stiff. 

The completed model

See Photo, y'all get a pretty good view of him from there.

Summary

For the very low price of $2.00, you get a clown, somthing we haven't seen in SYSTEM before, not counting Batman's Joker.  For me, it is just a step closer to me being able to make a custom Ronald McDonald.  All I need is a better clown face.  (Ominous tone) And I know what the future brings, skater boyII/ surfer girl all over again. . . .

 

As someone who is afraid of Clowns, (especially Ronald McDonald) in a comical way, I must say that this was not a musthave but the Series 1 musthave.  Though, be warned, I have been drawn to less popular/wanted figures, like the Racecar Driver.

 

Included Custom Torso

I don't expect anybody to use this torso, I have it here for my own personal reference.  Please do not mark this review as unhelpful because of it.  Thank You.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Hey, hey, kids, it's... Bricky the Clown.
review:
Set #8683 Circus Clown: I got him with my second Nurse and I was actually glad to see him, although the Circus Clown isn't on my must have list for Series 1 I definitely don't scoff owning him. Every good City display can use a clown or two.

 

His unique hairpiece and fun looking horn accessory are pretty nifty looking and the printing on this guy is really fun. If you're looking to get a lot of unique mini-figures then you can't go wrong with the new Collectible Mini-Figures and there's nothing more unique than a circus clown. Perhaps LEGO will make a new set next year for the CITY theme that can go with him. A miniature Circus tent or something the size of the Farm, with camels and elephants and new LEGO lions and tigers... Yeah that'd really enahnce this little dude, but if they don't at least we have a Circus Clown to lighten the moods of the LEGO City Citizens.

author: B21
title: My first CMF
review:
Circus Clown 

This was my first Collectible Minifigure from Series 1 and in my opinion, still remains as one of the best Collectible Minifigures to this day. 

The Molds?

This figure includes two new molds, which is very impressive for Series 1 back in 2010. These molds include a new horn piece and an Afro piece. To my knowledge the horn hasn't been used for anything except the Clown Minifig but the Afro has come if a few different colors over the years.

The Prints

The prints on this minifigure are also great. It comes with a yellow face with clown makeup, which is very nice to have, as well as some torso and leg printing you can see below. There is no printing on the back or sides.

Overall

This is a great minifigure with great parts and was one of the few Collectible Minifigures that costed $1.99. If you see it for cheap I highly recommend picking it up.

author: sideswinger
title: An amazing figure!
review:
So the Circus Clown was the fourth figure in the LEGO Minifigures Series 1, and for 2010 this is an incredible figure. I just love the pieces and prints and everything about him. So let's get a closer look!

Starting at the top, he has this really amazing hair piece. It's just an incredible piece overall. I love how poofy it is, as well as the elaborate moulding all over it. And it looks great in red as well. The piece was new for the figure too, which makes it a lot cooler, and for 2010 it looks great. It does appear more with future CMF's, but never in red, so that's cool.

And next is his face, which looks cool. I love that big smile, with the white makeup and all, and then he also has those big painted white eyes. But of course, the best bit is his big red clown nose. It's just very necessary for a clowning figure. No alternate face on him though, which is to be expected from a two dollar figure.

Then we have his torso which looks sweet. I love how colorful it is. You have that red bow tie up top with the white polka dots on it, and then he has those blue straps on him as well which look neat. And then he also has those white polka dots under those straps. It's just a pretty complex design. And no back torso printing either.

And his legs are next, and I like how they're two different colors, with the red and blue. Then I also like how the patches on the legs are the opposite color, which is just very clever by LEGO.

And then we have his great accessory, which is that horn piece. And it is just an extremely awesome piece, with that handle and everything. I just love how that piece turned out, with the black on the end. And it was new for the figure too which is cool, and it is a very uncommon piece from my understanding. So all cool there.

And I think that;s it for this figure! It s definately one of my top favorites of Series 1, and he's just all around, an excellent figure. I think he was a great choice as well. And the fact that back in the day he was only worth two bucks, is just really amazing. Now he's rather steep online, but if you wanted to pay that price,I don't think you would be disappointed whatsoever. He's just an awesome figure, in my opinion. So I hope this review was helpful, and thanks for reading!
